question_text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive muscle pain. The pain started in the shoulder muscles and then spread to the arms, back, and legs. She often feels stiff in the morning but does not have significant joint pain. She reports that she has had trouble sleeping because of the pain and cannot concentrate during the day. Medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder. Her only medication is sertraline. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears tired. Examination shows tenderness in the arms and legs and along the axial skeleton. There is no joint swelling. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.4 g/dL, an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 10 mm/h, and a creatine kinase concentration of 55 U/L. Results of other laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive muscle pain. The pain started in the shoulder muscles and then spread to the arms, back, and legs. She often feels stiff in the morning but does not have significant joint pain. She reports that she has had trouble sleeping because of the pain and cannot concentrate during the day. Medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder. Her only medication is sertraline. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears tired. Examination shows tenderness in the arms and legs and along the axial skeleton. There is no joint swelling. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.4 g/dL, an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 10 mm/h, and a creatine kinase concentration of 55 U/L. Results of other laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's history of chronic, widespread muscle tenderness, morning stiffness, fatigue, cognitive dysfunction (difficulty concentrating), and sleep disturbances, in conjunction with normal laboratory studies, suggests fibromyalgia (FM). FM mostly affects women between the second and fifth decade of life and is often associated with psychiatric disorders, such as depression.
learning_objective: Recognize fibromyalgia, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Electromyography (EMG) is used in the diagnosis of neurogenic and myopathic disorders, such as inflammatory myopathies, which manifest with muscle tenderness. However, inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) and muscle enzymes (e.g., creatinine kinase) are typically elevated in inflammatory myopathies. This patient most likely has FM, in which EMG is not needed to establish the diagnosis.

Muscle biopsy is used in the diagnosis of inflammatory myopathies, such as polymyositis (PM) and dermatomyositis (DM), which manifest with muscle tenderness. However, inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) and muscle enzymes (e.g., creatinine kinase) are typically elevated in inflammatory myopathies. This patient most likely has FM, in which muscle biopsy is not recommended.

Prednisone is used in the treatment of autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and polymyalgia rheumatica (PR). SLE affects women more often than men and can manifest with myalgias and fatigue. However, this patient does not have other common findings in SLE, such as skin involvement (e.g., the typical butterfly rash), joint pain, fever, and weight loss. PR mainly affects women older than 50 years of age and manifests with stiffness and pain in the shoulders, hips, or neck, as well as systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, malaise, and depressed mood). In contrast to what is seen in this patient, ESR is typically significantly elevated.

Although ketorolac is often used in the treatment of moderate to severe pain, treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and/or acetaminophen has not been proven effective in patients with FM and should, therefore, be avoided.

Regular exercise can reduce pain and improve functional capacity in patients with FM; cardiovascular training (e.g., swimming, walking, cycling) is recommended. Patients with FM should be advised to increase daily physical exercise gradually and that it is normal to initially experience a temporary worsening of myalgias. In addition, initial management of FM should include patient education (including reassurance about the disease and its prognosis and the importance of nonpharmacological measures such as sleep hygiene), treatment of comorbidities (e.g., mood and sleep disorders), and pharmacotherapy with low-dose tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline). Cyclobenzaprine, selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (e.g., duloxetine), or anticonvulsants (e.g., pregabalin, gabapentin) can also be used as initial pharmacotherapy.
Opioid therapy (e.g., with oxycodone) has not been proven effective in the treatment of chronic pain in patients with FM and should, therefore, be avoided.

question_text: A 78-year-old man receiving home hospice care for advanced metastatic prostate cancer is examined at home at the request of his wife. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer 10 months ago, and the cancer has metastasized to his lower spine, pelvis, right femur, liver, and lungs despite hormonal ablation therapy. The patient declines chemotherapy. His wife reports difficulty managing her husband's pain and that he is restless. He has avoided solid food for the past 2 weeks and has lost weight. He often coughs after drinking water. Current medications include oxycodone as needed, extended-release morphine, and lactulose. The patient appears to be in moderate distress. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 121/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased skin turgor and dry mucous membranes. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is severe tenderness to palpation of the lower back, and the patient is unable to sit up on his own due to pain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 78-year-old man receiving home hospice care for advanced metastatic prostate cancer is examined at home at the request of his wife. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer 10 months ago, and the cancer has metastasized to his lower spine, pelvis, right femur, liver, and lungs despite hormonal ablation therapy. The patient declines chemotherapy. His wife reports difficulty managing her husband's pain and that he is restless. He has avoided solid food for the past 2 weeks and has lost weight. He often coughs after drinking water. Current medications include oxycodone as needed, extended-release morphine, and lactulose. The patient appears to be in moderate distress. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 121/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased skin turgor and dry mucous membranes. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is severe tenderness to palpation of the lower back, and the patient is unable to sit up on his own due to pain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This terminally ill patient has insufficient pain control, as evidenced by his restlessness, tachycardia, and tachypnea.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate non-oral form of analgesia for chronic cancer-related pain management.

answers.explanation_why: Palliative radiotherapy can help manage pain caused by bone metastases but brachytherapy, which involves placing a radioactive object as close to or within the tumor, is typically used for primary tumor management; this form of radiotherapy is not used for palliative management of metastatic disease. External beam radiation therapy and intravenous injection of bone-targeted radioisotopes are the radiotherapy modalities used to manage pain caused by bone metastases.

This patient is in distress due to insufficiently controlled pain, and he has dysphagia. Accordingly, his oral medications should be reduced as much as possible, and a non-oral form of analgesia is the most appropriate next step in management. Fentanyl is a synthetic full opioid agonist with a higher potency than morphine. The transdermal formulation of fentanyl is indicated in the treatment of chronic cancer-related pain, providing steady analgesia because it diffuses continuously into the blood.

Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine that can be used for the management of anxiety and restlessness. This patient's restlessness and distress, however, are most likely due to insufficient pain control. In addition, the coadministration of benzodiazepines and opioids increases the risk of severe CNS and respiratory depression.

Codeine is an oral medication used in the management of mild to moderate pain and is a potent cough suppressant. Although this patient has insufficient pain control and a cough, the symptom of coughing while swallowing indicates oropharyngeal dysphagia and a high risk of aspiration. Therefore, a medication that can be administered via a non-oral route should be considered. In addition, codeine is less effective in patients with liver disease (like this patient with liver metastasis) because it is a prodrug that relies on hepatic metabolism to achieve its analgesic effect.

answers.content: Have the patient crush his morphine pills and take them with soft foods
answers.explanation_why: This patient with dysphagia may be experiencing severe pain because of an inadequate intake of oral pain medication due to an inability to swallow pills. Crushing pills and mixing them into foods may facilitate medication adherence. However, this patient has been prescribed extended-release morphine. Extended-release formulation drugs should never be crushed because of the risk of toxicity from dose dumping.

question_text: Two weeks after undergoing below-knee amputation of the left leg, a 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of episodic sharp, shooting, and burning pain below the amputation site. She is in the military reserve and was involved in active combat 2 weeks ago, during which she sustained multiple gunshot wounds to her left lower leg resulting in irreversible limb ischemia. She is currently taking oral acetaminophen, which has provided minimal pain relief. The patient has a history of bronchial asthma for which she uses an albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 123/75 mm Hg. Physical examination of the residual limb shows mild erythema and drainage of a scant amount of serous fluid from the sutured wound. Muscle strength in the hip and upper leg is normal bilaterally. Sensation to pain and temperature is normal in the left upper leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Two weeks after undergoing below-knee amputation of the left leg, a 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of episodic sharp, shooting, and burning pain below the amputation site. She is in the military reserve and was involved in active combat 2 weeks ago, during which she sustained multiple gunshot wounds to her left lower leg resulting in irreversible limb ischemia. She is currently taking oral acetaminophen, which has provided minimal pain relief. The patient has a history of bronchial asthma for which she uses an albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 123/75 mm Hg. Physical examination of the residual limb shows mild erythema and drainage of a scant amount of serous fluid from the sutured wound. Muscle strength in the hip and upper leg is normal bilaterally. Sensation to pain and temperature is normal in the left upper leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's reporting of new-onset neuropathic pain in her left lower limb despite having undergone left-sided below-knee amputation two weeks ago suggests phantom limb pain.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for phantom limb pain.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical revision is indicated in postsurgical complications, such as residual limb infection, scar formation, or seroma. This patient's residual limb shows mild erythema and warmth of the overlying skin, which is normal during the first two weeks after surgery. Furthermore, she does not have any systemic signs or symptoms of an infection.

Ibuprofen, a nonopioid analgesic, is one of the preferred first-line treatments for mild to moderate pain. This patient's pain symptoms are more consistent with neuropathic pain, for which ibuprofen is not typically effective. Also, this patient's asthma limits the use of ibuprofen and other NSAIDs as these drugs can precipitate bronchoconstriction.

Spinal cord stimulation is a neuromodulation technique used to relieve chronic neuropathic pain (i.e, lasting > 6 months). It can be used as a second-line treatment for phantom limb pain. As this patient has only had pain for three days, other conservative modalities should be attempted before considering a spinal cord stimulator implant.

Opioid analgesics (e.g., oxycodone) can be used to treat moderate to severe pain. For patients with neuropathic pain, other forms of pharmacotherapy should be attempted first and opioid analgesics should be used as a last resort.

Certain anticonvulsants (e.g., gabapentin) and antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline) can be used to treat neuropathic pain, including phantom limb pain. Because there is insufficient research on treatment for phantom limb pain, a multimodal approach is typically recommended. Other forms of first-line treatment for phantom limb pain include mirror therapy, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, and pharmacotherapy with NMDA receptor antagonists. Note that phantom limb pain can only be diagnosed after the exclusion of other causes of stump pain (e.g., infection, ischemia, post-surgical neuroma).

question_text: A 22-year-old man with sickle cell disease comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of severe pain in his upper back. He reports that the pain started after a housewarming party at which he consumed multiple alcoholic beverages. He does not have a cough, chest pain, or shortness of breath. He drinks alcoholic beverages occasionally but does not use illicit drugs. Medications include hydroxyurea and folic acid. He looks uncomfortable and is unable to sit up in the examination bed. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 121/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 10,200/mm^3, and creatinine concentration is 1.2 mg/dL. In addition to intravenous morphine therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man with sickle cell disease comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of severe pain in his upper back. He reports that the pain started after a housewarming party at which he consumed multiple alcoholic beverages. He does not have a cough, chest pain, or shortness of breath. He drinks alcoholic beverages occasionally but does not use illicit drugs. Medications include hydroxyurea and folic acid. He looks uncomfortable and is unable to sit up in the examination bed. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 121/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 10,200/mm3, and creatinine concentration is 1.2 mg/dL. In addition to intravenous morphine therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient with sickle cell disease (SCD) presents with acute back pain most likely caused by vasoocclusive crisis due to erythrocyte sickling.
learning_objective: Recognize vasoocclusive crisis in sickle cell disease, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Chest x-ray is the next step in management of suspected acute chest syndrome (ACS) in patients with SCD. Although ACS can be precipitated by vasoocclusive crisis, this patient does not have symptoms of this condition (e.g., fever, cough, chest pain, respiratory distress), and his oxygen saturation is within normal limits.

answers.content: Transfusion of packed red blood cells
answers.explanation_why: Transfusion of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) decreases morbidity and prevents recurrence in patients with vasoocclusive events such as acute chest syndrome, stroke, hepatic sequestration, and multiorgan failure. However, there is no evidence that transfusion of pRBCs benefits patients with ongoing uncomplicated vasoocclusive crises.

answers.content: Blood cultures and empiric antibiotic therapy
answers.explanation_why: Blood cultures followed by empiric antibiotic therapy are the appropriate management for suspected osteomyelitis. Patients with SCD are at high risk for infection with encapsulated bacteria (e.g., S. pneumoniae) due to functional asplenia, and vertebral osteomyelitis manifests with back pain. However, this patient has no systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever, leukocytosis).

Hydroxyurea is the first-line agent for the prevention of vasoocclusive crises in SCD, but it is not used for treatment. Patients taking hydroxyurea should continue their regular dose if there are no signs of cytopenia on CBC. Uptitration, if needed, typically occurs in the outpatient setting, and CBC and reticulocyte count should be monitored every 4 weeks for myelosuppression.

Administration of intravenous (IV) fluids is the most appropriate next step in the management of vasoocclusive crisis, which was most likely precipitated by alcohol consumption in this patient. Alcohol inhibits antidiuretic hormone secretion and reduces water absorption in the kidneys, which leads to dehydration and increased risk of erythrocyte sickling. Oral rehydration or IV fluids are appropriate for euvolemic patients. In general, IV fluids should be used judiciously because overhydration can trigger or exacerbate acute chest syndrome. Because hypoxia can worsen erythrocyte sickling, patients with SpO2 of < 95% should be given supplemental oxygen. In addition, pain should be managed with opioids in most patients.

question_text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient to refill her prescription for hydrocodone. She recently moved to the city. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with shingles and subsequently developed postherpetic neuralgia. She was treated with capsaicin cream, pregabalin, and lamotrigine. She says that none of the medications provided sufficient pain relief until she started taking hydrocodone 1 year ago. Additional medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder, for which she takes sertraline. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine immunoassay screening is negative for opioids but positive for benzodiazepines. Upon discussing the results with the patient, she claims that she has not taken any benzodiazepines. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 64-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient to refill her prescription for hydrocodone. She recently moved to the city. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with shingles and subsequently developed postherpetic neuralgia. She was treated with capsaicin cream, pregabalin, and lamotrigine. She says that none of the medications provided sufficient pain relief until she started taking hydrocodone 1 year ago. Additional medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder, for which she takes sertraline. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine immunoassay screening is negative for opioids but positive for benzodiazepines. Upon discussing the results with the patient, she claims that she has not taken any benzodiazepines. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Urine drug screening is performed in all patients who receive chronic opioid therapy to monitor adherence and ensure patient safety. Urine immunoassay (UIA), a qualitative test, is the most commonly used screening method but it has several limitations.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step after unexpected urine drug screening results.

answers.explanation_why: Discontinuation of opioid therapy by cross-tapering to a nonopioid pain medication (e.g., naproxen) may be considered if the patient has a substance use disorder that would make concomitant opioid use dangerous or if opioid diversion is suspected. However, a negative result for opioids on UIA alone is insufficient evidence of drug diversion, and conclusions about a substance use disorder cannot be made from UIA alone.

answers.content: Discontinue hydrocodone until the urine drug test is negative for benzodiazepines
answers.explanation_why: Concomitant use of benzodiazepines and opioids can lead to severe CNS and respiratory depression and should generally be avoided. UIA has several limitations, as false positive results for benzodiazepines can occur due to the intake of a drug with a similar structure, such as sertraline. Unexpected results should therefore be discussed with the patient and further investigated before making therapeutic decisions.

UIA has a high incidence of false negatives as it may not reliably identify synthetic (e.g., fentanyl) and semisynthetic opioids (e.g., hydrocodone), and cross-reactivity with other medications and foods can cause false positive results (e.g., sertraline for benzodiazepines, poppy seeds for opioids). Therefore, unexpected results should be discussed with the patient to find possible explanations before drawing presumptive conclusions about treatment nonadherence, recreational substance use, or drug diversion and before making any therapeutic decisions. Results may also be discussed with laboratory personnel who can aid with interpretation. If no explanation is found, confirmatory testing with urine chromatography is necessary to reliably detect and quantify concentrations of specific drugs and their metabolites.

answers.content: Refer the patient to an addiction specialist
answers.explanation_why: Referral to an addiction specialist is indicated in patients who have a substance use disorder with recreational or prescription drugs. UIA can detect certain drugs in urine (suggesting recent use) but it cannot diagnose substance use disorder, which is why unexpected results should be discussed with the patient and further investigated before making therapeutic decisions.

answers.content: Report the patient to the law enforcement authorities
answers.explanation_why: Reporting a patient to law enforcement may be considered if there is a high suspicion of drug diversion or theft. However, a negative result for opioids on UIA alone is insufficient evidence of drug diversion. Because of the limitations of UIA, unexpected results should be discussed with the patient and further investigated before drawing conclusions.

Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: African-American, self-identified
Site of Care: clinic
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have burning pain on the right side of my body, even at the lightest touch.”
History of Present Illness:

1-month history of right-sided burning pain and intermittent paresthesia in the extremities
pain exacerbated by touch and movement; severity 9/10; refractory to acetaminophen and ibuprofen

3-month history of memory disturbances, sleep disturbances, and fatigue

hypertension

learning_objective: Recognize thalamic pain syndrome (central poststroke pain).

answers.explanation_why: Thalamic pain syndrome (central poststroke pain; Dejerine-Roussy syndrome) commonly follows posterior cerebral artery stroke, which typically involves the thalamogeniculate arteries or the posterior choroidal arteries and leads to damage in the ventral posterolateral nucleus. Characteristic symptoms are initial paresthesia followed by neuropathic pain, allodynia, and dysesthesia. These symptoms typically occur on the contralateral side if the trunk and extremities are affected and in the hemifacial region ipsilateral to the stroke. Management of thalamic pain syndrome involves a multidisciplinary approach that integrates pharmacological, physical, and psychological interventions, along with comorbidity management and patient education. Invasive treatment (e.g., deep brain stimulation) may be considered if the pain is refractory to conservative management.

Fibromyalgia manifests with diffuse musculoskeletal pain, which is commonly neuropathic and often accompanies paresthesia, memory disturbances, and fatigue. However, pain at tender points across the body is expected rather than allodynic hemisensory pain.

Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is characterized by pain that is excessive in duration or severity in proportion to the inciting event. The pain is often accompanied by allodynia and hyperesthesia. However, CRPS typically follows limb trauma, and sudomotor or vasomotor features are expected, such as hypothermia/hyperthermia, hypopigmentation/hyperpigmentation, and hypohidrosis/hyperhidrosis.

Diabetic neuropathy manifests with dysesthesia and may also lead to paresthesia, allodynia, and muscle weakness. However, diabetic neuropathy typically consists of distal symmetrical sensory loss (stocking-glove distribution) with a proximal progression rather than a hemisensory distribution.

Postherpetic neuralgia is characterized by allodynia, paresthesia, and dysesthesia following herpes zoster (shingles). However, pain typically follows the dermatomal distribution of the rash rather than a hemisensory distribution.

question_text: A 65-year-old man with a history of depression, obesity, and peripheral neuropathy due to type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the office for a follow-up evaluation. He has gained 7 kg (15 lb 7 oz) recently and has become more sedentary, which has worsened his neuropathic pain and depression. His score on the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ)-9 is 5, indicating mild depression. He used to run regularly but stopped 10 years ago after moving to a new home. He briefly started swimming 5 years ago but has only returned to the pool once in the past two months to join his wife for an aquatic therapy class. Although his wife attends twice a week, he hasn't felt motivated to join her consistently. The physician feels that lifestyle changes may help alleviate both pain and depression, and engages the patient in a conversation integrating features of motivational interviewing. The patient recognizes a need for lifestyle changes and writes down several goals to work towards before his next appointment. Which of the following is the most appropriate goal to establish with this patient?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man with a history of depression, obesity, and peripheral neuropathy due to type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the office for a follow-up evaluation. He has gained 7 kg (15 lb 7 oz) recently and has become more sedentary, which has worsened his neuropathic pain and depression. His score on the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ)-9 is 5, indicating mild depression. He used to run regularly but stopped 10 years ago after moving to a new home. He briefly started swimming 5 years ago but has only returned to the pool once in the past two months to join his wife for an aquatic therapy class. Although his wife attends twice a week, he hasn't felt motivated to join her consistently. The physician feels that lifestyle changes may help alleviate both pain and depression, and engages the patient in a conversation integrating features of motivational interviewing. The patient recognizes a need for lifestyle changes and writes down several goals to work towards before his next appointment. Which of the following is the most appropriate goal to establish with this patient?
hint: SMART goals are utilized for quality improvement but are also beneficial in chronic illness management.
learning_objective: Choose a SMART goal to enable behavioral change.

answers.content: "From now on, I will start running one mile each day."
answers.explanation_why: Setting a goal to run a mile each day is unrealistic for this patient, given his current condition, and there is no time frame specified for this goal.

answers.content: "In the next 3 months, I will exercise more and lose 10 pounds of weight."
answers.explanation_why: Without a specific action plan, a goal to exercise in the next 3 months is too broad and vague. Moreover, the goal should focus on a process within the patient's control rather than an outcome that may not be entirely controllable (e.g., "losing 10 pounds").

answers.content: "In the next 4 weeks, I will go to aquatic therapy class at least once per week"
answers.explanation_why:
Asking the patient to join his wife for aquatic therapy class at least once per week for the next 4 weeks fulfills all the requirements of a SMART goal. It identifies a specific action to perform, it can be measured, it is achievable and relevant for this patient (especially since he has done this class before and has enjoyed being in the pool when he was swimming), and it pinpoints a time frame. SMART goals help the patient be more realistic about the expected benefits of therapy and link treatment outcomes to functional improvements. These personalized goals also help the clinician understand the patient and learn what is most important to them. The action should preferably be framed positively (e.g., "I will do...") rather than negatively (e.g., "I will not...") and should focus on a process within the patient's control (e.g., "attending aquatic therapy class once a week") rather than an outcome that may not be entirely controllable (e.g., "losing 10 pounds"). The goal should be challenging yet achievable to avoid diminishing the patient's self-efficacy through repeated failure.

For patients with chronic pain, SMART goals help connect treatment decisions to specific benefits, set realistic expectations for analgesic therapy, and facilitate discussions on pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic pain management options. An important aspect of setting a SMART goal is following up with the patient within a specified time frame to assess whether they are achieving the goal, to identify potential barriers to achievement, and to reassess the goal.

answers.content: "Six months from now, I will be less depressed and have less pain."
answers.explanation_why: Becoming less depressed and having less pain are vague goals without a specific action plan.
